: When I stumbled upon the 2020 Tagalog animated movie "Hayop Ka
", I had no idea what I was getting myself into here
But I read the synopsis for it, and have to say that I was somewhat intrigued, as "Hayop Ka
" sounded like something definitely aimed at a more mature audience
And I will say that writers Manny Angeles, Avid Liongoren and Paulle Olivenza definitely managed to put together a story and plot that was every bit as entertaining as it was enjoyable
So yeah, "Hayop Ka
" was a wholesome animated feature for a mature audience
And when I say mature audience I don't mean that it is XXX-rated, but merely that there were references and hits towards lewd nature
The art style in "Hayop Ka
" was strange, but enjoyably so

Initially I was a bit taken aback by the art style, but it quickly grew on me and I came to enjoy the art style that they used here because it was definitely complimenting the story and the message of the movie
With "Hayop Ka
" being an animated movie, a proper voice cast ensemble is a must
And luckily they did have that here
While I am not familiar with Tagalog cinema, then I wasn't familiar with a single voice here
But I will say that the voice acting was good and definitely gave the characters life on the screen
I found "Hayop Ka
" to be an enjoyable surprise of a movie, and definitely is an animated movie that I would recommend for a mature audience that enjoys light-hearted and funny stories
The fact that "Hayop Ka
" was told as an animation wasn't really a hindrance in any way
My rating of director Avid Liongoren's "Hayop Ka
" lands on a six out of ten stars

Pros:

Character Designs and Animations - Let's go ahead and point this out
I thought the designs for the characters were unique
To the point where I can easily identify where these characters came from
Not only that, but the animation was beautiful

Repeating Premise with a Surprise - It has been done to death Yes
A female that's tired of her broke life so she wants a chance at the richness and luxury
That's pretty much what Nimfa does in this movie
She leaves her ex to join the rich and luxurious life
Except instead of realizing she was better off with her old life, she doesnt get neither men

So even with my skewed expectations for this film, I still do hope that this would fare better, and
It does, but it does not at the same time
So I may as well start out with the cons before the pros, and these have to do with the story and themes itself and how the tone can clash with the animation

Given that it's rated 18, the themes that it tackles do fit well, but how they are executed is in poor taste, which does remind me of how Saving Sally executes its own mature themes, but at least this film gives these themes a bit more room for discussion, even if it's dealt with in a sour, and sometimes questionable manner
The story is simple yet dramatic and can hit some good moments
I just wished it was a bit longer and does not cut through dramatic scene to dramatic scene so quickly, which made the resolution and ending so spotty, unsatisfying, and utterly rushed

The overall tone can clash with the animation in a consistent way, as some scenes do not mesh well with the hyperbolic nature of the animation, which can make some of the melodramatic scenes to be unfit and oddly uncomfortable with the cinematic and energetic flow of the animation
Pushing the flaws aside, I will say that the animation is excellent all throughout
Smooth, expressive, and gives the characters a lot of personality
The backgrounds are detailed with anthro versions of real-life brands, mottos, and references which gives more attention to detail to the movie
And the performances for the most part are also in their A-game as well, especially Angelica Panganiban

Even despite my mixed feelings for this movie, I still do want to convince everyone to watch the film, because if the film managed to succeed in its streaming sales, then that would determine how many animated films would go down the line in the years to come

Even with all the controversy behind it recently, we want "Hayop Ka
" ("You Animal
") to succeed
The film is a technical marvel with its animation and is truly a showcase on what our local artists can do
But nothing can save it from its very simple and one-sided characters and narrative - that have no redeeming values or whatsoever
Nimfa Dimaano (Angelica Panganiban) is a pretty cat who works as a perfume sales lady at a department store
Her boyfriend is Roger (Robin Padilla) who works as a janitor and already happy and satisfied with his standing in life
But Nimfa wants more and when she meets Iñigo Villanueva (Sam Milby), a super rich business dog, their chemistry ignites
Who will Nimfa choose
Roger’s unending love or Iñigo’s unending riches
Taking years to make, it seemed like much of the effort in creating "Hayop Ka
" was put into crafting its world of parody
If you're a Filipino viewer then every scene will be oozing with inside jokes that it was actually as amusing as the animation itself
Speaking of the animation, this is the strongest asset for "Hayop Ka
The colorful and vibrant environments and palette make every scene stand out and the 2D animation had the perfect mix of feeling nostalgic and modern at the same time
The voice acting was good but not great
While the voice actors themselves handled the script well, there's just this feeling that the visuals and audio didn't match up 100%
Unfortunately, the film had poorly-written characters and narrative
It was too simple to the point that the characters themselves were one-sided and extremely flawed
The characters do "bad things" and there's little chance for them to redeem themselves given the film's running time of 98 minutes
We understand that this is a raunchy comedy but putting non-redeemable characters just for the sake of being in tone with its theme was a bad decision in our opinion
Overall though, "Hayop Ka
" at least had excellent comedy and visuals that will make you laugh - just don't expect to get anything else from the experience

be/AJtDXIazrMoBeing Singaporean, it's such a pleasant surprise that Southeast Asian animation is getting better and better each year given that it's a very small industry in the region, even in 2020
I got to be honest, 2020 is the year where the small and low-budget animated movies managed to be at times on par with the mainstream giants
Hayop Ka (or You Animal), from the Philippines' Rocketsheep Studios (who also produced the unique hybrid movie "Saving Sally") should be included on that list

The story parodies on classic Filippino soap oprea tropes, in that it's a love triangle between a saleslady, her janitor boyfriend and a rich businessman whom she feel in love with the first time they encountered each other
One of the best things about the story is that it's one of the funniest animated movies of the year

The amount of animal-related puns, innuendos and sexual tensions justify the M18 rating there, but it also sacrificed the cohesion and flow of the love triangle, an absolute shame given that it's the writing that mainly let the whole movie down (also, a little bit too many storylines to cover in such a short frame)
Still, for their first animated movie attempt, the story is still enjoyable to a certain extent
But, let's talk about the most surprising element of the movie: the animation
This is easily well animated
I know I prefer 2D animation to 3D CGI, but for an animated movie made in the Philippines, this is a solid attempt
There are moments where the colours are a little bit flat, but when the animation gets dynamic, it shows the full potential of its animation and we rarely get this type of animation anymore
Kudos to the guys at Rocketsheep for such great animation
As for characters, most of the main cast are full realised, although given its 73-minute runtime, some of the development felt rushed
I feel for the main character Nimfa (voiced by Angelica Panganiban) as she struggled to keep her affection with the rich businessman a secret as well as the two main male leads
If the story is a letdown, the entertaining characters did not

I will give Hayop Ka credit for one thing: they should not be underestimated when it comes to low budget animated movies that came out in 2020, especially when it's easily one of the most entertaining low budget animated movies of 2020

It's currently available in most Asian countries that has Netflix, so if you can't wait to support Filippino animation but you are outside Asia, do keep a lookout for its release in other countries on Netflix

I wasn’t planning on writing reviews when i made a letterboxd account
I just wanted to lurk, read reviews, check out people’s lists, stalk user profiles and yes, read every single review to every movie I directed because i like crying myself to sleep at night
But after watching hayop ka and reading the reviews here, i was compelled to write something
Because i don’t get why people hate it so much
For me, it’s a dark comedy that tackles realities of class and socio-economic disparity in the Philippines
Nimfa’s problem is simple: she’s poor

She has to break her back working as a saleslady to pay for her sister’s tuition and pay rent, she has pares to look forward to during special occasions because that’s all she and her boyfriend could afford, she can’t even go to a motel for some sexy time
This isn’t necessary a problem except for one thing: Nimfa is dissatisfied
She is not happy with her situation
She wants more
But what can she do
She didn’t graduate and it’s very likely that she’ll be a saleslady forever
So can you really blame her when she “falls” for Iñigo
A handsome rich guy who showers her with attention
If you were in her situation, wouldn’t you
I would
So she makes one bad choice after another
Should we hate her for it
What would we rather see
Tanggapin nalang niya yung buhay niyang ganun
Ok lang yang pares ghorl masarap naman
Beauty in poverty ganun
She sees a way out, and she grabs it
I am not entirely happy with her choice but i understand why she did it
Eh sa sawa nang maging mahirap ’yung tao e
The bad choices that Nimfa makes are greatly influenced by her circumstances, circumstances that are forced upon her because she is poor
Yes cliche
Yes lagi nalang mahirap/mayaman storyline but maybe there’s a reason why the boss-katulong trope(the powerful loving the powerless) works so well in our country
Maybe it’s because most of us Filipinos still see that as the only means of escape
And hayop ka lays bare that truth: If you’re poor, falling in love out of economic need is very much a reality
This truth is prevalent in our narratives, even if they aren’t explicitly stated
Some top of mind examples are Laida Magtalas falling in love with sir Miggy(A very special love) or Maya with Sir Chief(be careful with my heart)

Fuck i’m old The difference in hayop ka is that it does away with romantics and explicitly states, with ice cold pragmatism: I am in love with you because I am poor, because you are my best option to escape this life
It’s tragic how in the world presented in hayop ka, genuine romantic love is a privilege for the rich
And another note, can i just say that the art direction is fucking gorgeous
Making drawings move is an expensive and time-consuming affair and you have to find ways to get your point across in as few frames as possible
Hayop ka borrows some techniques from Japanese animation which it uses brilliantly and comically
Future animations will surely use this film as a reference

Liongoren's Hayop Ka

is a tongue-in-cheek and provocative 2D animated film seen from the perspective of proletariat catwoman Nimfa Dimaano, as she finds herself slowly loosening her morals in desperate exchange of economic indemnity

The film is deceptively simple, but functions intelligently to provide a scathing representation of the cyclical, problematic lives of the working class Filipino: their desensitisation to the methods they cling onto for their own economic benefit, the internalized sexist and especially misogynistic paradigm that remains hegemonic among both Filipino men and women, and how all this disturbingly becomes the mundanity of everyday life in a third-world country

Moreover, although the narrative might simply appear as an animated rehash of what has plagued local TV for years, it cleverly utilizes these teleserye tropes to construct a sociological examination on capitalism's destruction to society; more specifically, to the Filipinos that belong to the lower end of the social strata

Past the painfully realistic reconstruction of the plight of the working class in film, the portrayal on the bourgeoisie is also excellently handled; they're cruel and selfish, despite the already comfortable lives that they live
Hence, the anthropomorphism of these animals becomes a clever display of how capitalism has made literal animals out of us— easily succumbing to carnal desires and almost devoid of empathy
Aside from the thematic complexity of Hayop Ka
, the meticulously beautiful animation is extremely noteworthy as well
Sadly, this film has been misread by most of its viewers— its intelligent writing and thematic complexity ignored due to its vulgar, yet realistically absurd humor
Needless to say, Hayop Ka
is up there thematically, and can even suffice to be the lovechild of two classics that eloquently critique capitalism: last year's Parasite, and 1962 Mexican film The Exterminating Angel

There are a couple of things one needs to know prior to delving into a satire like Hayop Ka
The Nimfa Dimaano Story
First: the film is inspired by popular Filipino telenovelas
These beloved soap operas usually feature characters who scream “Hayop Ka
,” which translate to “You Animal
” or “You Son of a B****”, in the height of conflict
The fact that the central figures in director Avid Liongoren’s cheeky animated comedy are, in fact, animals should tell you what type of film you are watching
The second thing to note is that shock jock radio hosts have increasingly become surrogate therapists for those who lack the funds to get professional advice
This is a double-edged sword though as the hosts usually turn the caller’s personal hardships into humiliating spectacles for ratings
While this unfair trial by public opinion appears in the later sections of the film, Hayop Ka
The Nimfa Dimaano Story keeps its feet firmly in the soapy waters of melodrama throughout

The first time I watched Hayop Ka
, I honestly just saw it as a bastos movie, parang puro kabastusan lang HAHA
But upon rewatching it, I realized the concept is actually liberating and surprisingly close to reality
Its vibrancy and exaggerated humor felt more like satire—a playful but biting critique of how consumerism shapes the world we live in
Through a realist lens, the film mirrors the everyday struggles of many Filipinos, though wrapped in an animated, comedic package
The stark contrast between the rich and the poor was a constant theme
How privilege dictates not only opportunities but also relationships
Even love in the film is framed by class and material wealth, showing how affection is often entangled with survival and status
From a Marxist perspective, Nimfa’s relationships expose how capitalism and consumerism seep into our most intimate desires

Her dissatisfaction with her current boyfriend and her attraction to a wealthier partner may seem superficial at first, but it reflects how the system conditions people to equate love with upward mobility and financial security
The film satirizes how consumer culture commodifies even emotions and human connection, turning them into transactions rather than purely personal bonds
Looking at it through feminist theory naman, my initial impression of Nimfa as "malandi" for wanting more felt unfair
On rewatch, I realized this judgment reflects how women are often shamed for pursuing their desires, especially if those desires break away from traditional expectations

The film suggests that Nimfa’s choices are not purely personal flaws but rather shaped by the larger forces of patriarchy and capitalism, where women are pressured to chase an “ideal” version of love, security, and femininity
It questions why women are criticized for seeking better lives, while men who fail to provide are rarely scrutinized in the same way
In the end, Hayop Ka

may seem chaotic and shallow at first glance, but digging deeper, it becomes a satirical mirror of our society; where class, consumerism, and gender roles intersect to shape even the most personal aspects of life like love and relationships

If ever there was a movie I wanted to have a conversation about, this is it, because I fail to see why this really fun, slightly dramatic, but overall interesting slice of life is so universally panned
I think it goes without saying to praise the animation in Hayop-ka - it’s smooth and moves fluidly, it leaves itself open for some really impressive expressions and powerful images in scenes
The backgrounds are picturesque, and create a very vivid feeling of what this version of the Philippines is like: lively, energetic, maybe a little crowded but full of interesting characters

I think it’s worth mentioning, too, how good these backgrounds are at communicating different regions: the scenic beach near the luxury cabin, the quiet village that’s contrasted by its tight knit sense of community, both contrasted against the usual setting of the city

And while I’ve seen in other reviews that people find the innuendos in the background jokes to be tacky or in poor taste, I actually found that not only were a lot of them funny, but I think it creates a tangible sense of a world populated by Anthro animals more than other media tends to
I think sex is a pretty natural human experience, and a lot of real life marketing sells sex very transparently, and lots of mainstream Anthro animation doesn’t address that
It’s outside the ratings for films like Zootopia and Sing, and sexuality is so central a focus of a story like Beastars that normalizing it would kind of destroy its themes
And I think that perhaps Hayop-Ka’s depiction of sexuality in this world is one of its greatest strengths
Which, I guess, is interesting, because it seems like part of the negative backlash to Hayop-Ka is the accusation that is perverse or obscene for its sexual nature
Which seems… weird to me
The sex isn’t explicit in it, and Nimpha is only pictured having sex in the film once
The films setting is steeped in sexuality: sexuality is marketed on every sign on every street, and Nimpha’s motivation is mostly based around sex,But it doesn’t feel that weird I guess

It’s a story about an adult woman making adult choices, and the use of sexuality is only out of place because it’s animation - but there’s a lot of animated stories that are a lot more sexual than this
And like I said, I think the sexuality makes the plot kind of interesting

By the third act, the novelty of animal-sex-world kinda dies off, and the film isn’t really about that, as it becomes a series of Nimpha making increasingly more destructive decisions with basically everyone involved in her life
But by that point in the film, I had already been hooked in, and I was interested in what would happen to Nimpha

The positive sexual expression was a great hook for the first act, and moving into the second and third, I cared enough about the established characters enough to weigh the morality of their decisions in my head
Nimpha does something objectively bad to Roger, but it is understandable that she wants to better herself, and Roger’s tendency towards violence make him seem like a less dependable partner

But Inigo’s a literal villain, and if him talking about partnering with Elon musk didn’t telegraph that enough, he is a character who openly talks about working with the Filipino president to keep wages down
When Nimpha confronts her family in the third act, she’s objectively wrong, but I can’t really be mad at her, because it’s a realistic emotional outburst
I’ve watched a lot of stories about bad people who misuse sexuality in their lives

And I’ll never claim that Hayop-Ka - an animated parody of soap operas meant to poke fun at infidelity - is even half as weighty as Tár or Bojack Horseman - heavy commentary about how celebrity is used to leverage power
But, I do file this movie in a similar place in my head
Watching a not great person try to be better and trying to figure out why things are so messy
And frankly
I actually adore the ending for that
Because Nimfa does fuck up, she does do bad things, but people in her life do bad things back to her
And in the end the best thing Nimfa can do is just… walk away
Start a new life
And she does and I think that’s beautiful
I do think it’s worth mentioning the sexist overtones in the climax of the movie - when Nimfa calls the radio station
A reference to an unfortunately very real trend of men berating women for doing anything other than serving whatever man is already present in her life
I feel like part of the negative reception of Hayop Ka is that people read this as him being right but like… no
He’s just not

Maybe it’s my prior knowledge making me biased against a man in a recording booth telling a woman how to live her life, but in that moment I think it’s Nimfa’s last attempt to rely on men, and her faith in it is shattered when she talks to Inigo again
Because yeah - don’t know if you notice - she can’t even try to follow that bull’s advice, because she never gets a chance to come clean to Inigo if she wanted to
And I think that Nimfa marching for maternity leave and raising her child on her own with her family shows that Nimfa’s life isn’t going to revolve around the approval of men anymore
It’s possible that’s cope: that this is a sexist message I’m jumping through hoops to spin in a way that empowers the protagonist in the end
But I dunno, I kinda constructed that reading without thinking about it
I don’t think it’s that much of a stretch
I’m going to be coming back to Hayop-Ka at some point, for sure
It’s filed in my brain alongside a lot of my favorite depictions of every day life in an animal world
It’s a little melodramatic, but I do think that the depiction of Nimfa, and how her story ends, does tell a good, grounded story
I think I, a bunny, am always going to be happy with a film that I start and whose title very loudly says to me,“You’re an animal”

Ralph Bakshi’s cult feature debut ‘Fritz the Cat’ gets a sort of a spiritual successor in romantic satire ‘You Animal
’ – a tongue-in-cheek parody of Pinoy telenovelas in which characters reportedly scream the titular phrase at each other in the heat of an argument

Deliciously saucy and irreverently melodramatic, it revolves around a love triangle between a saleslady or rather, salescat, Nimfa, her macho mongrel boyfriend, Roger, who works as a janitor, and a purebred (husky
) playboy industrialist, Iñigo Villanueva, with whom she fulfills her fantasy of climbing up the social ladder
(Did I mention that the story is actually prophesized by an octopus fortune teller

)The colorfully mesmerizing artwork may look cute, with all protagonists being talking animals, but this is by no means a kids cartoon, given its rampant sex jokes and lines such as “my bun is quite content with your hot dog”, not to mention a highly stylized (read: deliberately kitschy) intercourse scene

However, it is not to be taken too seriously either, which Liongoren and his team of artists constantly emphasize through visual gags such as witty inscriptions hanging all around ‘Zootopia-fied’ Manila, some literal catfight or a rage-fueled scene inspired by the ‘Street Fighter’ car-crashing bonus game
The social commentary is there, but it is the animators’ wild and free imagination that comes first, reflected in a wonderful world building, and full control of the medium
